Automating the Learning Schedule for Students via Chatbots

A learning guide that reminds when to study and motivates you

COMPANY Prepathon (now Oheyo), I worked for this company 2 years back so, the product itself has changed in due course)

DURATION 1 week (Design Sprint)

CONTRIBUTION Individual Contributer

üßë‚Äçüîß The Challenge

At the start, the product had human coaches to help students. Many students have different study schedules. Coaches were not available at night, hence we came up with the idea to complement coaches with study bot.

Automating the personal coach with a chatbot who can prepare and help students to remain on their study schedule

ü•Ö Goals


To provide round the clock support to student create and maintain a consistent study schedule
Goal 1


Keep the students informed about their progress and nudge on the right track
Goal 2

ü§† Outcomes


Reduced dependence on human coaches and wait time
Outcome 1


A study bot also increased course completions
Outcome 2

üî¨ Concept and User Research (Initial 2 days)

Prepathon (now Oheyo) was a platform having courses on various entrance exams in India. Initially, prepathon had a team of coaches who would help students to answer questions and guide students in their courses.

I did five interviews with my friends preparing for competitive examinations to gauge how they maintain study schedules. In addition, we had a numerous feedback from students through the customer service team which were analysed to come up with the scenarios for the study bot.

A large number of students study all over the day and also at night

Human coaches are not available at night (Prepathon did not employ night shift coaches)

Students need quick responses to their queries

Though we had the course platform but the course completion rate was low mostly due to lost interest or irregular study schedules

üì± Visual Designs (Next 2 days)

Since, the product was already in production, we utilized the existing designs to build upon the scenarios got from user research.

SCENARIO 1: Students are notified about the weekly schedule. They can choose the difficulty of pace

SCENARIO 2: When the app is not open, a notification is sent to the phone with an action buttion to get the user started

SCENARIO 3: Reduce the messages to once a day if user is inactive for 3 days

SCENARIO 4: When the user is on a different part of app, the notification is presented in-app

SCENARIO 5: We would send a message if some topic is left by the student unfinished

SCENARIO 6: When the student completes an exercise, the studybot suggests them a new exercise

SCENARIO 7: Change of pace - If the student is unable to complete the suggested topics for three consecutive days then the studybot suggests to slow down the pace

SCENARIO 8: Within the homepage of the course, topics are also suggested as recommendations to the students

üîÆ Reflections (Final Day)

I tested the prototype with five friends. They were satisfied with the scenarios covered

They mentioned that the notifications should be less and not intrusive even it is to help them

They also suggested to use an avatar for the bot if possible which can make personalised statements
